questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the vulva?
questions.solution:
Cervix is not a part of the vulva. 

The vulva includes:

  • Mons veneris
  • Labia majora
  • Labia minora
  • Clitoris
  • Vestibule
  • Vestibular bulb
  • Greater vestibular glands.

The vulva is posteriorly related to the perineum. 

The triangular space bounded by clitoris, labia minora and fourchette is the vestibule. It is present between the labia minora anteriorly and the introitus posteriorly. The posterior part of the vestibule between the fourchette and the vaginal introitus is called fossa navicularis. The vestibule has 4 openings:

  • Urethral opening
  • Vaginal orifice opening
  • Bartholin’s duct on either side
  • Ducts of paraurethral glands

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding labia majora?

choices.text: They join posteriorly to form the posterior commissure
It is homologous to scrotum in male
The round ligament terminates at its posterior end
It contains sebaceous glands and apocrine glands

questions.solution:
The round ligament terminates at the anterior end of the labia majora.

The labia majora lie on either side of the vulva and join posteriorly to form the posterior commissure. The inner side is hairless. Labia majora are homologous to the scrotum in males. The labia majora and the mons veneris contain:

  • Hair follicles
  • Sebaceous glands
  • Modified sweat glands, known as apocrine glands

The labia minora are two cutaneous folds between the labia major. Anteriorly they enclose the clitoris and unite with each other in front and behind the clitoris to form prepuce and frenulum respectively. The labia minora are homologous to the ventral aspect of the penis.

The clitoris is a small erectile body lying in the anterior-most part of the vulva. The clitoris is homologous to glans penis.

questions.text: A patient presented to the gynecology OPD with the following finding. Which structure in men is homologous to the affected structure?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a Bartholin's cyst, which involves the Bartholin's glands. These glands are homologous to the male bulbourethral or Cowper glands.

The ducts of Bartholin's glands open in the groove between the hymen and the labia minora at approximately 5 and 7 o’clock positions. They are stimulated by sexual arousal. The glands contain columnar cells that secrete mucus with lubricant properties. Contraction of the bulbospongiosus muscle expresses gland secretions.

Bartholin's cyst occurs due to obstruction of the ducts of the Bartholin's glands by proteinaceous material, or due to infection. Symptomatic or recurrent cysts may require marsupialization or gland excision. An infected Bartholin's cyst can lead to an Bartholin's abscess. This requires surgical drainage.

Related Pearl: Homologous structures in male and female genitalia

Females Embryonal structure Males
Ovary Genital ridge Testis
Ova Primordial germ cells Spermatozoa
Labia majora Labioscrotal swelling Scrotum
Labia minora Urogenital folds Ventral aspect of the penis - penile urethra
Glans clitoris Genital tubercle Glans penis

Vestibular bulbs

 		 Genital tubercle

Corpus cavernosum

Corpus spongiosum

Urethral and paraurethral glands /Skene's glands

Lower part of Vagina 		 Urogenital sinus  

Prostate gland
Greater vestibular glands/Bartholin's glands Urogenital sinus Bulbourethral glands/Cowper's glands
Granulosa cells Sex cords Seminiferous tubules and Sertoli cells
Round ligament Gubernaculum Gubernaculum testis
Epoophoron and paroophoron Mesonephric tubules Efferent ductules and paradidymis
Gartner duct (remnant structure) Mesonephric duct/Wolffian duct Epididymis, ductus deferens, and ejaculatory duct
Uterus, fallopian tube, cervix and the upper vaginal wall Paramesonephric duct/Mullerian duct Prostatic utricle and the appendix of testis (remnant structure)

questions.text: What is the pH of the vagina before puberty?
questions.solution:
The pH of the vagina before puberty is 7. In adult females, the pH is acidic. 

Doderlein's bacilli (Lactobacillus sp.) are part of the normal vaginal flora. They produce lactic acid from glycogen in the vaginal epithelium and make the vaginal pH acidic. They are present in newborns and disappear in 10-14 days. They reappear at puberty and disappear after menopause. Vaginal flora also includes microbes such as Clostridium welchii.

Vaginal defence mechanisms are influenced by estrogen. In newborns, maternal estrogens maintain the defence mechanisms for 10-14 days. After that, the levels wane. During puberty, the circulating estrogen maintains the defence mechanism. 

Period Vaginal pH Doderlein bacteria Types of cells
Birth-2 weeks 4-5 + -
2weeks-puberty >7 - Parabasal cells
Puberty 4-4.5 sparse Superficial & intermediate
Reproductive 4-5 plenty Superficial & intermediate
Pregnancy 3.8-4.1 plenty Intermediate 
Postmenopause >7 - Parabasal

 

Note: The pH is higher in the upper part of the vagina due to mixing with alkaline cervical mucus.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about relations of the vagina?
questions.solution:
Bartholin’s gland is present lateral to the vagina. 

The vagina is related to the following structures:

  • Anteriorly:
    • Bladder (upper 1/3rd)
    • Urethra (lower 2/3rd)
  • Posteriorly 
    • Pouch of Douglas 
    • Ampulla of the rectum
    • Perineal body
  • Laterally
    • Mackenrodt's ligament
    • Levator ani
    • Bartholin's glands

questions.text: Identify the type of hymen.
questions.solution:
The given image shows cribriform hymen because it has multiple small openings.

Based on the shape of its opening, the hymen may be classified as:

Hymen Description
Annular Oval central opening
Crescentic Semilunar central opening
Vertical Vertical slit-like opening
Septate 2 lateral openings partitioned by a bridge of hymenal tissue
Cribriform Multiple small openings

Other variants of the hymen:

Variants Description
Absence of hymen Congenital deformity.
Infantile Small central linear opening.
Imperforate No opening
Fimbriated

Free margin has symmetrical indentations anteriorly
Ring or fringe-like 

A narrow ring of thick membrane is present all around the vaginal orifice

It can easily distend during sexual intercourse without rupturing the hymen

The hymen is lined by stratified squamous epithelium on both sides. The hymen is most commonly torn posterolaterally or posteriorly. It is replaced by tags after childbirth which are called as carunculae myrtiformes.

questions.text: A patient with uterine prolapse and urethrocele has weakness in the superficial and deep perineal muscles. What level of support is lost here?
questions.solution:
In the given case scenario, level 3 supports including the superficial and deep perineal muscles are lost. This causes urethrocele.

DeLancey's levels of support are used to describe the supports of the genital organs.

Related Pearl: DeLancey's levels of support of the genital organs

Level of support Structures forming the support Consequence of damage
Level 1

The cardinal-uterosacral ligament complex provides apical attachment of the uterus and vaginal vault to the bony sacrum

Uterine descent

Vault descent

Enterocele
Level 2

Lateral attachments provide support to the middle part of the vagina. The anterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to arcus tendinous fascia pelvis and the posterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to the facia overlying the levator ani muscle. 

Cystocele

Rectocele
Level 3

The urogenital diaphragm (Deep perineal muscles & Perineal membrane) and the perineal body provide support to the lower part of the vagina. 

Urethrocele

Gaping introitus

Deficient perineum

questions.text: Anteflexion of the uterus is at the level of ___.
questions.solution:
Anteflexion of the uterus is seen at the level of the internal os. 

Angle of Anteversion Angle of Anteflexion
The angle between the cervix and vagina The angle between cervix and uterus
90o 120o

(Mnemonic - V for version, V for vagina)

The uterus normally lies in a position of anteversion and anteflexion.

In the anteverted position, the external os is directed downward and backwards. On vaginal examination, the fingers come in contact with the anterior lip of the cervix as it is the lowest part.

When the uterus is retroverted, the cervix is directed downward and forwards. The lowest part of the cervix becomes either the external os or its posterior lip.

questions.text: A G3P2L2 woman presents in her third trimester with vaginal leaking. On PV examination, the anterior lip of the cervix can be palpated. What is the position of her uterus and the ligament that maintains this position?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the uterus is anteverted as the anterior lip of the cervix was palpable. The round ligament helps maintain the anteversion of the uterus during pregnancy. 

However, the anteversion in the non-pregnant uterus is maintained by both the uterosacral ligament and round ligament.

Angle of anteversion Angle of anteflexion
Angle between the cervix and vagina Angle between cervix and uterus
90o 120o

(Mnemonic - V for version, V for vagina)

The uterus normally lies in a position of anteversion and anteflexion.

In the anteverted position, the external os is directed downward and backwards. On vaginal examination, the fingers come in contact with the anterior lip of the cervix as it is the lowest part.

When the uterus is retroverted, the cervix is directed downward and forwards. The lowest part of the cervix becomes either the external os or its posterior lip.

Anteflexion is seen at the level of the internal os.

questions.text: A multiparous woman presented with a urethrocele, due to weakness of the urogenital diaphragm. What is this structure also known as?
questions.solution:
The urogenital diaphragm is also known as the triangular ligament. 

The urogenital diaphragm extends from the pubic arch anteriorly to the central point of the perineum posteriorly and consists of two layers of fascia through which pass the vagina and the urethra. The central point of the female perineum lies between the vagina and the rectum.

Urogenital triangle:

  • Present between 2 ischiopubic rami
  • Stretching transversely across the rami there are 3 membranes.
  • From above downwards the membranes are as follows:
    • Superior fascia of urogenital diaphragm
    • Inferior fascia of urogenital diaphragm
    • Membranous layer of superficial perineal fascia

questions.text: What is the cavity of the uterus lined by?

choices.text: Single layer of ciliated columnar epithelium
Double layer of ciliated columnar epithelium
Single layer of ciliated cuboidal epithelium
Double layer of ciliated cuboidal epithelium

questions.solution:
The uterine cavity is lined by a single layer of ciliated columnar epithelium.

The wall of the uterus consists of 3 layers:

  • Perimetrium is the serous coat adherent to the underlying muscle.
  • Myometrium - it consists of thick bundles of muscles that form 3 distinct layers during pregnancy:
    • Outer longitudinal
    • Inner circular
    • Middle interlacing called living ligature
  • Endometrium - It is the mucous lining of the cavity. It consists of lamina propria and surface epithelium which is a single layer of ciliated columnar epithelium.

questions.text: A woman with regular menstrual cycles is undergoing an ultrasound on the 14th day of her cycle. What will the endometrial thickness be?
questions.solution:
During ovulation, the thickness of the endometrium is around 11 mm.

Phase Endometrial thickness
Immediately after menstruation 1-2 mm
Early proliferative phase 5-7 mm
Secretory phase 7-16 mm
Preovulatory phase  up to 11 mm
Postmenopausal <4 mm
Postmenopausal - abnormal, requires biopsy >4 mm

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding uterine anatomy?

choices.text: Round ligaments receive their blood supply from Sampson's artery
Transverse cervical ligaments are also called cardinal ligaments
Uterine innervation is by the pudendal nerve plexus
Lymphatic drainage is primarily to the obturator, internal and external iliac nodes.

questions.solution:
The uterus is innervated by the fibers of the uterovaginal plexus, also known as the Frankenhauser ganglion.

Option A: Round ligaments receive their blood supply from Sampson's artery which represents the anastomosis of the uterine artery and ovarian artery.

Option B: The cardinal ligaments are also called transverse cervical ligaments or Mackenrodt ligaments. They consist primarily of perivascular connective tissue. They attach to the posterolateral pelvic walls near the origin of the internal iliac artery and surround the vessels supplying the uterus and vagina.

Option D: Lymphatic drainage of the uterus is primarily to the obturator and internal and external iliac nodes. One theory of endometriosis, states lymphatic spread as cause for seeding in the pelvis.

questions.text: A gynecologist is performing a hysterectomy. She accidentally nicks the ureter in the ureteric canal as it pierces the Mackenrodt's ligaments. Which vessels are likely to be damaged here?

choices.text: Uterine artery above and the uterine plexus of veins below
Uterine plexus of veins above and the uterine artery below
Ovarian artery above and the uterine artery below
Uterine artery above and the ovarian artery below

questions.solution:
The uterine artery above and uterine venous plexus below are likely to be damaged here, as the ureter is present between these vessels. 

The ureter pierces the Mackenrodt's ligament, forming the ureteric canal. In this canal, the ureter is crossed by the uterine artery above and the uterine plexus of veins below, thus being present in between the uterine vessels.

The ureteric canal provides the necessary room for normal peristalsis, without pressure from the surrounding structures. After leaving the ureteric canal, the ureter passes forwards and medially to reach the bladder. It is 1-2 cm away from the cervix.

questions.text: You take a culture swab from the portio vaginalis of a woman having foul smelling vaginal discharge. What is this region also known as?
questions.solution:
Portio vaginalis or exocervix is the other name for the vaginal part of the cervix.

Cervix is the lowermost part of the uterus extending from the histological internal os to the external os. It is cylindrical in shape measuring 2.5 cm in length and diameter.

Cervix is made up of 10% muscle and the rest is collagen, elastin, and proteoglycan. The lining of the cervix has the following parts:

  • Exocervix - also known as portio vaginalis. It is lined by non keratinized stratified squamous epithelium.
  • Endocervix - it is lined by high columnar, ciliated epithelium. 
  • Endocervical glands - secrete alkaline mucus. When enlarged, they form swellings called Nabothian follicles/cysts. 
  • Transformation zone - the epithelium gradually changes from columnar to squamous in this region.

questions.text: What is the cervix: corpus ratio before puberty?
questions.solution:
The cervix:corpus ratio before puberty is 2:1.

The relationship between the length of the cervix and that of the body of the uterus varies with age.

Age Cervix/Corpus ratio
Before puberty

2:1
At puberty

1:2
Reproductive age 1:3 or 1:4
After menopause 2:1 - however, the uterus and cervix are both atrophied

questions.text: The remnants of Wolffian ducts in females are located in________.
questions.solution:
The Gartner's duct is a remnant of the Wolffian ducts in women. These are located in the broad ligament and the vagina.

The Gartner's duct is an embryological remnant of the mesonephric duct/Wolffian duct formed during the development of the urinary and reproductive organs. It runs parallel to, but below, the fallopian tube in the mesosalpinx. The duct passes downwards by the side of the uterus to the level of the internal os where it passes into the tissues of the cervix. It then runs forwards to reach the anterolateral aspect of the vaginal wall and may reach as far down as the hymen.

The duct can sometimes form a cyst in the broad ligament or in the vagina. It is called Gartner’s cyst. It is a benign condition and can be treated with marsupialization. 

Related Pearl: Homologous structures in male and female genitalia

Females Embryonal structure Males
Ovary Genital ridge Testis
Ova Primordial germ cells Spermatozoa
Labia majora Labioscrotal swelling Scrotum
Labia minora Urogenital folds Ventral aspect of the penis - penile urethra
Glans clitoris Genital tubercle Glans penis

Vestibular bulbs

 		 Genital tubercle

Corpus cavernosum

Corpus spongiosum

Urethral and paraurethral glands /Skene's glands

Lower part of Vagina 		 Urogenital sinus  

Prostate gland
Greater vestibular glands/Bartholin's glands Urogenital sinus Bulbourethral glands/Cowper's glands
Granulosa cells Sex cords Seminiferous tubules and Sertoli cells
Round ligament Gubernaculum Gubernaculum testis
Epoophoron and paroophoron Mesonephric tubules Efferent ductules and paradidymis
Gartner duct (remnant structure) Mesonephric duct/Wolffian duct Epididymis, ductus deferens, and ejaculatory duct
Uterus, fallopian tube, cervix and the upper vaginal wall Paramesonephric duct/Mullerian duct Prostatic utricle and the appendix of testis (remnant structure)

Related Pearl: Contents of the Broad ligament

  • One tube - Fallopian tube
  • Two ligaments:
    • Round ligament of uterus
    • Ovarian ligament
  • Two arteries:
    • Uterine artery
    • Ovarian artery
  • Two nerve plexus:
    • Uterovaginal plexus
    • Ovarian plexus
  • Three embryological remnants:
    • Epoophoron (Wolffian body)
    • Paroophoron (Wolffian body)
    • Gartner’s duct (Wolffian duct)
  • Other structures:
    • Lymph vessels and lymph nodes
    • Fibrous connective tissue

questions.text: Which of the following is false about the contents of the broad ligament?

choices.text: Ovarian vessels in its infundibulopelvic part
Ureter is present the lower portion
Ovarian ligament in its anterior fold

questions.solution:
The ovarian ligaments are contained in the posterior fold of the broad ligament.

The broad ligament contains the following parts:

  • Mesosalpinx - it lies between the fallopian tube and ovarian ligament. It contains the pelvic vessels - anastomoses between uterine and ovarian arteries. The ovary is attached via ovarian ligament through the posterior folds to the mesovarium. 
  • Mesometrium - it contains the ovarian vessels within the infundibulopelvic ligament.

The ureter is present in the inferomedial part of the broad ligament. It is related to the uterine artery here and may be damaged during hysterectomy.

Note: Broad ligament is not a support of the uterus.

Related Pearl: Contents of the Broad ligament

  • One tube - Fallopian tube
  • Two ligaments:
    • Round ligament of uterus
    • Ovarian ligament
  • Two arteries:
    • Uterine artery
    • Ovarian artery
  • Two nerve plexus:
    • Uterovaginal plexus
    • Ovarian plexus
  • Three embryological remnants:
    • Epoophoron (Wolffian body)
    • Paroophoron (Wolffian body)
    • Gartner’s duct (Wolffian duct)
  • Other structures:
    • Lymph vessels and lymph nodes
    • Fibrous connective tissue

questions.text: Where are Peg cells seen?
questions.solution:
Peg cells are seen in the fallopian tubes.

A peg cell is a non-ciliated epithelial cell within the fallopian tube. These cells are also known as intercalated or intercalary cells whose function is not yet known.

The image below shows pale ciliated cells (arrows) and narrow, dark, non-ciliated peg cells (arrowheads).

questions.text: What is the longest part of the fallopian tube?
questions.solution:
The longest and widest part of the fallopian tube is the ampulla (5 cm).

Related Pearl: Fallopian tube

Gross anatomy:

The fallopian tube is divided into the following parts:

  • Intramural/Interstitial portion:  
    • Intrauterine
    • The narrowest and shortest part
  • Isthmus:
    • The most common site for tubectomy
  • Ampulla:
    • The longest and widest part
    • The most common site for - fertilization and ectopic pregnancy
  • Infundibulum

Histology:

The ampulla, isthmus and infundibulum are extrauterine. They're covered by three layers: 

  • Mesosalpinx - It is the peritoneal layer. Also called serosa.
  • Myosalpinx - It contains smooth muscle and has 2 layers:
    • Inner circular 
    • Outer longitudinal
  • Endosalpinx - It is the mucosal layer. It has the following features:
    • Numerous branching folds, filling the entire lumen
    • Basement membrane
    • Ciliated, columnar epithelium 
    • Peg cells - non-ciliated epithelium. They help in the capacitation of sperms.

questions.text: Where is the tunica albuginea of the adult ovary derived from?

choices.text: The sub epithelial connective tissue layer

questions.solution:
Tunica albuginea of the adult ovary is derived from the sub-epithelial connective tissue layer.

Structure of the ovary:

  • Surface epithelium - a single layer of cuboidal cells is present, which later gives rise to the surface epithelium of the adult ovary. It is morphologically continuous with the mesothelium of the peritoneum.
  • The subepithelial connective tissue layer - gives rise to the tunica albuginea of the adult ovary and the basement membrane beneath the surface epithelium.
  • The parenchymatous zone - becomes the cortex and contains the egg nests and ovarian follicles. 
  • Zona vasculosa - becomes the medulla and contains the blood vessels. Hilar cells present here are homologous to interstitial cells of testes. They can rarely produce hilar cell tumors of the ovary.

questions.text: During the histopathological examination of an ovarian mass,  Call-Exner bodies are seen. In which of the following layers are these structures seen?
questions.solution:
Call-Exner bodies are formed by granulosa cells present within the granulosa cell layer of the ovary. 

They are small, distinctive, glandlike structures filled with acidophilic material, resembling immature follicles. They are characteristically seen in granulosa cell tumors of the ovary.

The image below shows Call-Exner bodies (circled in black).

Graafian follicle:

The mature Graafian follicle is spheroidal or ovoid in shape. It contains pent-up secretion known as the liquor folliculi. The lining consists of:

  • Theca externa
  • Theca interna - contain the theca cells 
  • Granulosa cell layer
  • Cumulus oophorus - projection of granulosa cells into the cavity of the Graafian follicle. It is also called the discus proligerus.

questions.text: Where is the sympathetic nerve supply of ovary derived from?
questions.solution:
The efferent preganglionic sympathetic fibres to the ovary are derived from the T10-T11 spinal levels.

These fibres travel to the prevertebral ganglia, where they synapse. The postganglionic sympathetic fibres arising from these ganglia contribute to the ovarian plexus, which innervates the ovary.

The ovarian plexus is a network of nerves comprising:
  • Postganglionic sympathetic fibres
  • Preganglionic parasympathetic fibres from the sacral outflow (S2-S4)
  • Visceral afferent fibres (responsible for transmitting sensory signals)

The ovarian plexus has two parts based on its connections:

  • Upper part: Derived from branches of the renal plexus and aortic plexus
  • Lower part: Derived from the superior and inferior hypogastric plexuses.

Related Pearl: Nerve supply in the pelvis

Organ   Spinal Segments   Nerves
Perineum, vulva, lower vagina S2–4 Pudendal, inguinal, genitofemoral, posterofemoral cutaneous
Upper vagina, cervix, lower uterine segment S2–4 Pelvic parasympathetic
Uterine fundus, proximal fallopian tubes, broad ligament T11–12, L1 Sympathetic via hypogastric plexus
Outer two-thirds of fallopian tubes T9–10 Sympathetic via aortic and superior mesenteric plexus
Ovaries T10-T11 Sympathetic via renal and aortic plexus and celiac and mesenteric ganglia

questions.text: Bleeding during normal menstruation occurs due to rupture of ____
questions.solution:
Rupture of the spiral arteries causes bleeding during normal menstruation. This is a branch of the uterine artery. 

The blood supply of the uterus is as follows:

Uterine artery→Arcuate artery→Radial artery→Basal artery→Spiral artery

questions.text: A uterine artery embolization is being planned for a patient with uterine fibroids. Blood flow in which of the following arteries will not be affected by this procedure?
questions.solution:
In the given case scenario, blood flow in the vaginal artery will not be affected, as it is not a branch of the uterine artery. The vaginal artery is a branch of the anterior division of the internal iliac artery. 

It is homologous to the inferior vesical artery in males. It supplies the vagina and the base of the bladder in women. It should not be confused with vaginal branches of the uterine artery.

Branches of the uterine artery:

  • Ureteric branch
  • Vaginal branches (descending) - these unite to form the anterior and posterior azygos arteries of the vagina
  • Circular cervical branch
  • Sampson's artery - it runs in under the round ligament. It represents the anastomosis of the uterine artery and ovarian artery.
  • Arcuate--> Radial--> Basal--> Spiral and straight arterioles of the functional layer of the endometrium

questions.text: A patient with stress incontinence required surgical management. While performing a Burch colposuspension, the surgeon approached the space of Retzius. What is this space also known as?
questions.solution:
The space of Retzius is the other name for prevesical or retropubic space.

Burch colposuspension is a procedure done to relieve stress urinary incontinence. If an extraperitoneal approach is selected, the retropubic space is entered by perforating the transversalis fascia layer of the anterior abdominal wall.

Once the retropubic space is dissected, the bladder neck and the vaginal fascia underneath are identified. The bladder is mobilized to the opposite side. At each side of the bladder neck, two to four, preferably non‐absorbable sutures are placed in the space of Retzius.

Note:The presacral space is a retroperitoneal space that lies between the peritoneum of the posterior abdominal wall and the sacrum. It contains the superior and inferior hypogastric plexuses. The sacral sympathetic trunk lies against the sacrum’s ventral surface.
